M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not willfully or negligently interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises.

M.G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter under M.G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this case involves a tenancy dispute within the jurisdiction of the Housing Court Department.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 5.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Municipal Court Division pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 5, as the subject property is located in Roxbury, a neighborhood within the City of Boston.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: (interpreting the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets and applies the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment (G.L. c. 186, § 14) to the context of criminal activity in common areas of public housing. It explains that the covenant protects tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy, can be breached by landlord omissions that make such interference a natural and probable consequence, and clarifies that while landlords need not provide specific security measures, they may be liable if they fail to take reasonable steps (such as removing unlawful nontenants) when their presence substantially impairs tenants’ use. This is a substantive interpretation of the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished… The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: (recognizing tenant remedies for landlord interference with quiet enjoyment).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses and applies the implied covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment as a tenant remedy against a landlord for conditions (repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions) that interfered with the tenant’s use of the premises. The court analyzes G.L. c. 186, § 14, explains that “quiet enjoyment” is a recognized tenant right with expanded statutory remedies, and holds that the landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary conditions leading to flooding constituted interference with quiet enjoyment (though the particular damages award was vacated as duplicative).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.… [G]em is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it… permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses quiet enjoyment only in passing and does not articulate any standard or definition for what constitutes a 'substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.' Its substantive analysis concerns recusal, Chapter 93A emotional distress damages, and warranty of habitability damages, not the elements or definition of a quiet enjoyment claim. Therefore, it cannot be relied on as authority for defining substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: [No clear definition or standard for 'substantial interference with quiet enjoyment' appears in the provided text. The case notes only that the tenant alleged 'breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14,' but the court does not analyze or define that concept in the opinion.]}

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: (landlord’s failure to repair constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment).
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and notes that a landlord’s negligent failure to address conditions that interfere with tenancy can violate it, but the court finds no such interference here because the landlord promptly made repairs. The case therefore does not stand for the general proposition that a landlord’s failure to repair constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment; instead, it holds that under these facts there was no breach of quiet enjoyment. It is not appropriate authority to cite as affirmative support for the claimed proposition.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. … Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. … We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: (affirming tenant rights under implied warranty of habitability).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted text is from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent, not the majority. While he agrees the old no-repair rule should be reconsidered and proposes an implied obligation tied to code compliance, he expressly *dissents* from the majority’s broader formulation of an implied warranty of habitability and criticizes it as overbroad and undefined. Therefore, this portion of the opinion does not affirm tenant rights under the implied warranty of habitability; it argues for a narrower, different approach and rejects the majority’s implied-warranty theory.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law. The court states the new rule to be that the landlord renting a dwelling unit impliedly warrants to the tenant "that the premises are fit for human occupation"... I dissent from the statement of such a broad and sweeping new rule...

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: (landlord liability for circumstances interfering with tenant’s enjoyment).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case directly holds that landlords can be liable for circumstances that substantially interfere with tenants’ quiet enjoyment—here, excessive noise from a bar the landlords leased to another tenant and had the power to control. The court emphasizes that liability can arise even without intent where the interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and the landlord has the right to control the objectionable conditions.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. … Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Armstrong v. United States Realty & Imp..raw_text: Armstrong v. United States Realty & Imp. Co., 181 Mass. 23 (1902)
Armstrong v. United States Realty & Imp..proposition: (early interpretation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment).

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses several landlord obligations arising under Massachusetts landlord–tenant law: the non-delegable duty (absent a written agreement) to provide heat and hot water under the State Sanitary Code, duties under the security deposit statute (G.L. c. 186, §15B), liability for rent overcharges under the Boston Rent Control Ordinance, and warranty of habitability issues. These are classic tenancy-law obligations, and the court applies and enforces them, so the case is properly cited for landlord obligations under tenancy law.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”
